Purpose/Objective: The goal of CATALIST-Uganda is to sustainably commercialize smallholder agriculture through improved productivity and market development, resulting in marketable surpluses that raise farm incomes in Uganda, and increase regional food security for the wider East Africa and Great Lakes Region. Starting with the 'pull' of the market by working with commodities for which there is strong demand, CATALIST-Uganda will employ a systems approach to develop integrated cropping systems around priority commoditiesIrish potato, cassava and ricecombined with an accelerated cluster development approach appropriate for Uganda. In addition to agricultural intensification, attention will be paid to input market development (both seeds and fertilizer), output marketing, linkages to Dutch and other agribusinesses and improvement of the policy environment. By the end of CATALIST-Uganda in May 2016, 100,000 smallholder farmers will have doubled yields, achieved a 50 percent increase in incomes, and produced an annual marketable surplus of 200,000 metric tons of cereal equivalents. This will contribute to the increased rural incomes and trade in Uganda and increased food security in the region..

Purpose/Objective: Improving food security and economic development The government of Uganda prioritizes agricultural development as the key approach for poverty reduction,food security and economic development. In its agricultural strategy it focusses on enhancing agriculturalproduction and productivity, access to markets, creating an enabling environment, and institutional development. through integrated seed sector development An integrated seed sector development (ISSD) programme has the potential to contribute to all these aspects. ISSD builds upon the strengths of both the informal (farmers and community8based) and formal (public and private) seed systems and seeks the integration of these. ISSD guides specific interventions in identified seed systems; linking food and seed security to private sector development; and aligning and harmonizing seed policies, programmes and practices. providing smallholder farmers access to quality seed. The ISSD Uganda programme aims to support the development of a vibrant, pluralistic, and market8 oriented seed sector, providing more than 100.000 smallholder farmers access to affordable quality seed of superior varieties. This will contribute to an increased income of small8scale farmers and an increased number of rural households that are seed and food secure. Output 1: Functional local seed businesses establishedLocal seed businesses (LSBs) can fill a gap in quality seed production for crops in which the commercial seed companies are not interested. LSBs may start from informal sector farmer groups or entrepreneurial farmers seeing business opportunities in the production and marketing of quality seed. At the end of theprogramme these farmers/farmer groups are producing and selling quality seed of locally preferred crops and varieties to local markets, and operate as local businesses. They are technically better equipped, commercially sustainable and more autonomous in their entrepreneurship. building on local initiatives and partnerships... The programme builds as much as possible on existing initiatives, i.e. searches for local partnerships with existing farmers/farmer groups that have experience in seed production, and want to become more autonomous seed entrepreneurs. The farmers/farmer groups are identified in the inception phase of the programme. working towards a more robust seed system, involving specifically marginalized groups Through LSB development the programme also focusses on those crops and varieties that are interesting,considering the effects of climate change on food security and resilience of small scale farmers, e.g. varieties of the drought resistant crop sorghum in the northern part of Uganda. Furthermore, focusing on local crops and varieties will be an opportunity to strengthen the integration of women in business; the programme pays attention to gender integration in all components. Crucial criteria for business success include market access (access to transport and roads) and competitive markets (competition with farmer8 saved seed and commercial seed companies). Additional selection criteria for the LSB locations and groups are established during the inception phase of the programme. strengthening farmer groups in their seed entrepreneurship. The programme supports men and women farmers/farmer seed producer groups in the development towards local seed businesses: farmers have skills in the production and marketing of quality seed; are involved in action8research, e.g. they test and identify the right varieties for their business; are more knowledgeable on technical, organizational and legal issues; have functional partnerships with other organisations; exchange experiences with other farmer seed producer groups; and have made infrastructural investments to improve their businesses. Action research is supported through MakerereUniversity and Gulu University. Partnering with three ZARDIs, and involving NARIs, NAADS, UCA, Universities and others  For appropriate local embedding and sustainable LSB development the ISSD programme will partner with three ZARDIs, and will host teams of seed and agribusiness experts at each ZARDI to support project implementation. ZARDIs will work with NARIs for access to varieties and breeders' seed; NAADS for advisory services and seed markets; UCA for the Area Cooperative Enterprise model; and SACCO's/MFI's for access to finance. The programme will work with those partners that already closely work with farmers on seed production and/or marketing. It will partner with Makerere University and Gulu University in linking research to LSB practice and providing an evidence basis to the LSB model and strategies for innovation. ...and linked with other on+going agricultural initiatives in Uganda. The programme links with those NGOs and farmer groups working on agriculture and value chain development through the EKN skills development project; training institutes like Gulu University through the NUFFIC/NICHE programme; and local production departments of NAADS and the ZARDI's in the respective districts and zones where farmer groups are located that work with the EAAPP and ATAAS programme. Output 2: Supportive public sector At the end of the programme a process is completed with the public sector organizations in finding new and complementary roles and a sustainable mode of operation in supporting other stakeholders in their efforts to produce and market quality seed. MAAIF, NARO (including EAAPP regionally managed by ASARECA), NAADS, Universities (Makerere, Gulu, etc.), NSCS, and others have increased their collaboration with, and work in partnership with commercial seed companies, local seed businesses and civil society organizations. to solve key bottlenecks in the seed sector Through innovative approaches a number of bottlenecks in the seed sector have been solved at an institutional level, in relation to seed quality control, access to foundation seed and variety release. In these issues the above mentioned and other public sector organizations have a clear role to play. The inception phase will provide guidance in the different innovation processes required for institutional change. ... uniting stakeholders in a seed platform for dialogue Through a multi8stakeholder seed sector platform, the programme aims to bring together seed sector stakeholders to jointly identify key bottlenecks in the sector that cannot be solved by any single stakeholder alone. This seed sector platform will be hosted under the APF Agri8Hub Uganda, and led by a decision8making body representing key seed sector stakeholders from the public, private, research and civil society sectors. first focussing on the establishment of a functional seed quality system At the end of the programme, a functional seed quality assurance system has been established. In this component the programme collaborates with public sector organizations like NSCS. In the new system public and private sector organizations assume new roles, allowing a sustainable system to cope with the Ugandan reality of different type of seed producers having different requirements on seed quality assurance. As such mechanisms and capacities have been developed and strengthened that allow accreditation, seed certification and Quality Declared Seed. 5 next on access to breeder/foundation seed At the end of the programme a sustainable breeder/foundation seed system has been established, in which NARIs, ZARDIs and LSBs can guarantee that quality breeder and foundation seed, of preferred crops and varieties, of the required quantity, is available to seed producers in time. and also on variety release. At the end of the programme an effective and efficient variety release mechanism is implemented that allows the varieties to go within a two8years period through the necessary trials. For this component the programme collaborates with NSCS and NARO, to build the necessary capacity, and explore what is the most effective mechanism.

Purpose/Objective: The proposed programme Agri Skills 4 You will contribute to the Agro-BTVET sector, with a strong focus on agricultural skills, to enhance access to and improve relevance of formal training and mobile training for youth and for small market oriented (women) farmers (to be). BTVET institutions, both accredited and not accredited, will play a crucial role in aligning the curriculum of the institution and community based training and in harmonizing different activities at all levels. This intervention bridges the gap between institutional and community based formal and non-formal skills training and enables a more focused and coordinated approach towards relevant skills training at different levels. The programme is centred on relevance, quality and accessibility of vocational agricultural education and training The key target groups of the programme are women and youth in Acholi, Lango and West Nile sub-regions of Northern Uganda. Youth, between 15 and 25 years old, will be targeted as they are currently mostly unemployed, but have the potential to become small market-oriented farmers. The total number of youth targeted will be 2,000 with 40% females to enable us to target especially the idle male youth. Women are already farming at small scale (low output with potential and some assets), but did not have the chance to be educated and skilled. Around 60% of the selected farmers will be female. The total number of farmers targeted will be 10,000. Also targeted are the public and private extension service providers, and eight BTVET institutions. The training will mainly focus on the practical aspect and will include other related skills like life skills, psycho-social support, trauma healing and Village Savings and Loans Associations (VSLA). Specific attention will be given to gender related issues incl. SGBV and sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Functional Adult Literacy (FAL) will be included if needed and various information and communication technologies will be used whenever possible.
